occurrences.line_text: And bake their sides vppon the cold hard stone,
These eyes him saw vpon the cold earth sprad,
Couer'd with cold, and wrapt in wretchednesse,
That giueth comfort to her courage cold.
On the cold ground, maugre himselfe he threw,
That the cold steele through piercing, did deuowre
And gainst the cold hard earth so sore him strake,
He lyes (said he) vpon the cold bare ground,
Ne could he brooke the coldnesse of the stony masse.
A streame of cole black bloud forth gushed fro[m]; her corse.
The morish Cole, and the soft sliding Breane,
Her coleblacke curtein ouer brightest skye,
And coleblacke steedes yborne of hellish brood,
Enwrapt in coleblacke clouds and filthy smoke,
His cole-blacke hands did seeme to haue beene seard
A streame of coleblacke bloud thence gusht amaine,
And kindling coles of lust in brutish eye,
And loue fresh coles vnto her fire did lay:
Coles of contention and whot vengeance tynd.
And kindling coles of cruell enmitie,
Did priuily put coles vnto his secret fire.
Like coles, that through a siluer Censer sparkle bright.
That Colin Clout should pipe as one most fit;
Poore Colin Clout (who knowes not Colin Clout?)
Poore Colin Clout (who knowes not Colin Clout?)
But cared more for Colins carolings
To Colins melody:
And on his collar laying puissant hand,
And his left hand vpon his collar layd.
She straightly straynd, and colled tenderly,
Vppon his iron coller griped fast,
With a strong yron chaine and coller bound,
Cold Coloquintida, and Tetra mad,
Did breath out bounteous smels, & painted colors shew.
But could not colour yet so well the troth,
Which chaunge of colour did perforce vnfold,
What colour were their waters that same day,
Colour thy name with foule reproaches rust.
Of colour rustie browne, but sure and strong;
To giue faire colour to that Ladies cause in sight.
That by his fellowship, he colour might
Glauce, what needs this colourable word,
Shakt his long lockes, colourd like copper-wire,
That I in colourd showes may shadow it,
Her mantle, colour'd like the starry skyes,
Had knowne right well with colourd ribbands drest:
For the rich mettall was so coloured,
How she the blame might salue with coloured disguize.
And cast her colours dyed deepe in graine,
On which was drawen faire, in colours fit,
With sundry colours, in the which were writ
Whose simple answere, wanting colours faire
But if in liuing colours, and right hew,
And with fresh colours decke the wanton Prime,
With thousand spots of colours queint elect,
He bare, and by the colours in his crest,
On which the winged boy in colours cleare
And thou, faire Phoebus, in thy colours bright
And wings it had with sundry colours dight,
More sundry colours, then the proud Pauone
As euer could Cameleon colours new;
So could she forge all colours, saue the trew.
So blind is lust, false colours to descry.
In which his Ladies colours were, did bind
Both clad in colours like, and like array,
That all men wonder at her colours pride;
Dismayd so with the stroke, that he no colours knew.
With fayned colours shading a true case:
Which carry colours faire, that feeble eies misdeeme.
And to the brim with Colt wood did it fill,
An ambling Colt, that is his proper owne:
Then breake the vow, that to faire Columbell
Comaunded them their daily workes renew,
His cause in combat the next day to try:
For with that Pagan proud he combat will that day.
The combat, which he with Sansioy did hould;
And cruell combat ioynd in middle space:
That with himselfe should combat for her sake,
To single combat with Sir Satyrane.
In which they two the combat might darraine.
And pointed for the combat twixt them twayne
He by his former combate would not bide,
To ioyne the combate with cruell intent;
Ne would I gladly combate with mine host,
Three combats ioyne in one, and to darraine
In combats of sweet loue, and with his mistresse toyed.
That he, wich earst them combatted, was Guyon bold.
An hony combe, the wakefull dogs espy,
The which he neuer wont to combe, or comely sheare.
Combing her golden lockes, as seemd her good:
And whiles he stroue his combred clubbe to quight
And whiles he combred was therewith so sore,
Whom when as he thus combred did behold,
A cloud of combrous gnattes do him molest,
And combrous conflict, which they did sustaine,
And streight his combrous armes aside did lay
Me no such cares nor combrous thoughts offend,
Or zeale of friends combynd with vertues meet.
Through his three bodies powre, in one combynd;
These two now had themselues combynd in one,
And both combynd, what euer chaunce were blowne,
Were with a snake, whose head & tail were fast co[m]byned.
And with thy mother milde come to mine ayde:
Come both, and with you bring triumphant Mart,
Come see, where your false Lady doth her honour staine.
His ship farre come from watrie wildernesse,
Why they were come, her royall state to see,
So well they sped, that they be come at length
And downe to Plutoes house are come biliue:
And come to fiery flood of Phlegeton,
Till they be come vnto the furthest part:
Vnto the place they come incontinent:
That they the woods are past, & come now to the plaine.
Haue thither come the noble Martiall crew,
Ere long they come, where that same wicked wight
To come vnto his wished home in haste,
Whe[n] houre of death is come, let none aske whence, nor why.
To come, and goe with tydings from the hart,
Come, come away, fraile, seely, fleshly wight,
Come, come away, fraile, seely, fleshly wight,
Which all so soone, as it doth come to fight,
From heauen to come, or thither to arise,
Ah no, said they, but forth she may not come:
Then come thou man of earth, and see the way,
Now are we come vnto my natiue soyle,
O gently come into my feeble brest,
Come gently, but not with that mighty rage,
But when he saw them come, he did them still forsake.
But death will neuer come, when needes require.
Did come too neare, and with his talants play,
For we be come vnto a quiet rode,
Come then, come soone, come sweetest death to mee,
Come then, come soone, come sweetest death to mee,
Come then, come soone, come sweetest death to mee,
To come, where vile Acrasia does wonne,
But after death the tryall is to come,
Till that they come vnto a forrest greene,
But whence should come that harme, which thou doest seeme
And come vnto an Island, waste and voyd,
And now is come to that same place, where first she weft.
Come thou (quoth he) and see. So by and by
To come to succour vs, that succour want?
Come hither, come hither, Ã´ come hastily;
Come hither, come hither, Ã´ come hastily;
Come hither, come hither, Ã´ come hastily;
That bad him come in haste. He by and by
Now bene they come, whereas the Palmer sate,
Vnto the castle gate they come againe,
The first of them could things to come foresee:
The waues come rolling, and the billowes rore
Now are they come nigh to the Bowre of blis
Come daughter come, come; spit vpon my face,
Come daughter come, come; spit vpon my face,
Come daughter come, come; spit vpon my face,
Of Neustria come roring, with a crew
But more that him he could not come to smite;
But more that with his foes he could not come to fight.
All that to come into the world desire;
Gan causen, why she could not come in place;
Euer to come into his clouch againe,
Nine times he heard him come aloft ere day,
As if his dayes were come to their last reach.
And how we with our foe may come to fight.
Abode, to weet what end would come of all.
Come see the secret of the life of man,
Which Cambell seeing come, was nothing slow
Who seeing him come on so furiously,
Ne let his speeches come vnto their eare.
For hardly could he come the carle to touch,
To come and shew themselues before the light,
To come, where he his dolors did deuise,
He chaunst to come where those two Ladies late,
To come forthwith vnto his Ladies bowre.
Thus hauing past all perill, I was come
Much dearer be the things, which come through hard distresse.
To come where thou doest draw them with desire:
To ioyne in one, ere to the sea they come,
Ne with th'eternall Gods to bancket come;
To come of him, for vsing her so hard,
Ne any of them durst come in his way,
He chaunst to come, whereas two comely Squires,
He chaunst to come, where happily he spide
That she a Queene, and come of Princely kynd,
Ne would she stay, till he in place could come,
Come home to her in piteous wretchednesse,
Who seeing him come still so fiercely on,
To messengers, that come for causes iust:
He mote not come, to wreake his wrathfull mood.
Can not come neare him in the couert wood,
They to Mercillaes pallace come,
The marshall of the hall to them did come;
Whom when she saw so ioyously come forth,
Did thither come, where she afrayd of nought,
He this same day, as I that way did come
But when he felt him shrinke, and come to ward,
Ere he doe come, he should be soone in place.
He spide come pricking on with al his powre and might.
We chaunst to come foreby a couert glade
That ere they come vnto their aymed scope,
He chaunst to come whereas a iolly Knight,
Ne scarse wyld beasts durst come, there was this wights abode.
Ne could it vpward come, nor downward passe,
Who now come to himselfe, yet would not rize,
He chaunst to come, far from all peoples troad,
That good should from vs goe, then come in greater store.
But now I come into my course againe,
And to the Clergy now was come at last;
Did yield her comely person, to be at my call.
Thereby his mortall blade full comely hong
And entertaines with comely courteous glee,
Right cleanly clad in comely sad attire;
With goodly grace and comely personage,
The comely virgins came, with girlands dight,
Of comely seruices, or courtly trayne?
His carriage was full comely and vpright,
A comely Palmer, clad in blacke attire,
A sober sad, and comely curteous Dame;
And comely courted with meet modestie,
Vnworthy of faire Ladies comely gouernaunce.
Who with bold grace, and comely grauitie,
And fowly battered his comely corse,
That with thy brutenesse shendst thy comely age,
With comely compasse, and compacture strong,
Downe to the ground, a comely personage,
A carefull man, and full of comely guise:
A comely personage of stature tall,
Vnder that Porch a comely dame did rest,
And streight of beasts they comely men became;
And comely glee of many gracious
Without regard of grace, or comely amenaunce.
A iolly person, and of comely vew;
A comely knight, all arm'd in complete wize,
Set by it selfe, and ranckt in comely rew:
In that foule plight a comely personage,
They bene ybrought into a comely bowre,
She came in presence with right comely grace,
With comely haueour and count'nance sage,
And with her feeble feet did moue a comely pace.
The which he neuer wont to combe, or comely sheare.
And her against sate comely Curtesie,
And sad Asopus, comely with his hoarie head.
Adorn'd with honor and all comely grace:
He chaunst to come, whereas two comely Squires,
Spinning and carding all in comely rew,
Timely to ioy, and carrie comely cheare.
With curteous words, in the most comely wize;
And on their heads with long locks comely kemd,
Then is the bloosme of comely courtesie,
To which he adding comely guize withall,
When as by chaunce a comely Squire he found,
And forth together rode a comely couplement.
A faire young Mayden, full of comely glee;
That for these Carles to carry much more comely were?
And comely carriage of her count'nance trim,
As comely carriage, entertainement kynde,
And to recomfort him, all comely meanes did frame.
Into their comely tresses dewly drest,
To which no wit of man may comen neare;
But when as Calidore was comen in,
And vnto Morpheus comes, whom drowned deepe
But to the virgin comes, who all this while
So forth she comes: her brightnesse brode doth blaze;
So forth she comes, and to her coche does clyme,
And to the Paynims lodging comes with silent pace.
And forth he comes into the commune hall,
Soone after comes the cruell Sarazin,
At last forth comes that far renowmed Queene,
But comes vnto the place, where th'Hethen knight
For loe he comes, he comes fast after mee.
For loe he comes, he comes fast after mee.
Speake, O deare Lady speake: help neuer comes too late.
From thence it comes, that this babes bloudy hand
Perdy (said he) here comes, and is hard by
She comes vnsought, and shonned followes eke.
For yonder comes the prowest knight aliue,
Now comes to point of that same perilous sted,
When forth from virgin bowre she comes in th'early morne.
For soone comes age, that will her pride deflowre:
For soone as maisterie comes, sweet loue anone
Against their forrein foe, that comes from farre,
He comes not here, we scorne his foolish ioy,
Like as the tide that comes fro th'Ocean mayne,
Sweete is the loue that comes alone with willingnesse.
he comes to Proteus hall,
Who all that comes doth take, and therewith fill
So comes it now to Florimell by tourne,
Britomart comes to Isis Church,
Till that, as comes by course, I doe recite,
To whom Sir Calidore yet sweating comes,
Now comest thou to rob my house vnmand,
What frayes ye, that were wont to comfort me affrayd?
To comfort her, and feare to put away,
Yet outwardly some little comfort shewes:
My last left comfort is, my woes to weepe and waile.
But be of cheare, and comfort to you take:
As feeling wondrous comfort in her weaker eld.
But wise Speranza gaue him comfort sweet,
And comfort those, in point of death which lay;
For them most needeth comfort in the end,
And offred hope of comfort did despise:
What comfort can I wofull wretch conceaue,
But now, faire Ladie, comfort to you make,
He gan to comfort, and his wounds to dresse.
Yet in himselfe some comfort he did find,
Voide of all succour and needfull comfort:
That quickned the dull spright with musicall comfort.
And euermore himselfe with comfort feedes,
To comfort him in his infirmity;
And do her comfort, she mote algates dye.
They both conceiuing hope of comfort glad,
Many meeke wordes, to stay and comfort her withall.
To whom the Prince; Dwarfe, comfort to thee take,
But both of comfort him thou shalt depriue,
Comfort to him, that comfortlesse now lay.
She cast to comfort him with busie paine:
To comfort me in my distressed plight?
Her Amoretta cald, to comfort her dismayd.
The comfort of her age and weary dayes,
Without all hope of comfort or reliefe,
Great comfort of her presence he conceiued,
Therefore, faire Sir, do comfort to you take,
Henceforth faire Lady comfort to you take,
His dearest loue, the comfort of his dayes,
And heauy heart with comfort doth reioyce.
Whereto great comfort in her sad misfare
Did comfort take, or in his troubled sight
But comfort take: for by this heauens light
Withouten comfort, and withouten guide,
Striuing to comfort him all that they can,
Giue her great comfort, and some harts content.
To all, that shall require my comfort in their smart.
Gaue vnto her great comfort and reliefe,
Then it was wont, through comfort of this noble knight.
And she take comfort, which God now did send:
Such secret comfort, and such heauenly pleasures,
And for their better comfort to them nigher drew.
In stead of comfort, which we should embrace:
Yet had no meanes to comfort, nor procure her glee.
That giueth comfort to her courage cold.
In euils counsell is the comfort chiefe,
To seeke some comfort in that sorie case.
Finde harbour fit to comfort her great neede.
Which may her feeble leaues with comfort glade.
Began some smacke of comfort new to tast,
Whom hauing laid in comfortable couch,
Her selfe she set, and comfortably cheard;
And comforted with curteous kind reliefe:
But he her comforted and faire bespake,
But th'other forst him stay, and comforted in feare.
Her wisely comforted all that she might,
Therewith much comforted, she gan vnfold
Deepe, darke, vneasie, dolefull, comfortlesse,
The pitteous maiden carefull comfortlesse,
From whom returning sad and comfortlesse,
Them comfortlesse, through tyranny or might:
Comfort to him, that comfortlesse now lay.
The more t'augment her price, through praise of comlinesse.
Hath now made thrall to your commandement,
She would commaund the hastie Sunne to stay,
She would commaund, themselues to beare away,
At his commaund, and reared him vp light
Who fares on sea, may not commaund his way,
At thy commaund lo all these mountaines bee;
Eftsoones his heaped waues he did commaund,
Bad her commaund my life to saue, or spill.
To th'insolent commaund of womens will;
The which did her co[m]maund, without needing perswade.
And had the chiefe commaund of all the rest,
Commaunded them their fury to refraine,
Commaunded was, who thereby did attend,
Thence she commaunded me to prison new;
Who full of scorne to be commaunded so,
Commaunded straight his armour to be brought,
Commaunded him from slaughter to recoyle,
From her faire eyes he tooke commaundement,
So greatly his commaundement they feare,
To the long raynes, at her commaundement:
Her teme at her commaundement quiet stands,
For he had giuen streight commaundement,
But streight he held his hand at his commaundement.
And kept so well his wise commaundements,
And the fiers Carle commaunding to forbeare,
Commaunding Proteus straight t'enlarge the mayd,
His name hight Order, who commaunding peace,
That her commaundment he could not withstand,
Of commen wealthes, of states, of pollicy,
And commen to his reskew, ere his bitter bane.
(As often falles) of sundry things did commen.
And passing litle further, commen were,
He thus began: Where shall I then commence
The mightie martiall hands doe most commend;
Of his deare safetie, I to thee commend;
About Cairmardin, and did it commend
Him to commend to her, thus spake, of all well eyde.
Some baser metall, which commend he will
And Lindus that his pikes doth most commend,
And them amongst, her glorie to commend,
Vnto his soueraine Queene her suite for to commend.
That euery action doth them much commend,
Gan highly to commend the happie life,
He would commend his guift, and make the best.
Could not maligne him, but commend him needs:
Now Cantium, which Kent we commenly inquire.
To ward the same, nor answere commers call.
The day is spent, and commeth drowsie night,
Who with the noyse awaked, commeth out,
On who so commeth nigh; yet nigh it drawes
So fitly now here commeth next in place,
On man and beast, that commeth in her path.
The which as commeth now, by course I will declare.
And comming where the knight in slomber lay,
She findes forth comming from her darkesome mew,
Who comming to that soule-diseased knight,
Which comming downe to ground, does free it selfe by fight.
Till comming to this well, he stoupt to drincke:
And comming close to Trompart gan inquere
Did fiercely shake, and rowze, as comming late from rest.
It booted nought Sir Guyon comming neare
Till that the villein comming to their ayd,
Tho comming to his Squire, that kept his steed,
For of their comming well he wist afore,
And comming forth, shall spred his banner braue
And comming to the place, where all in gore
He comming home at vndertime, there found
He comming present, where the Monster vilde
And comming to that Fishers wandring bote,
And comming nigh, eftsoones he gan to gesse
And comming him before, low louted on the lay.
Her cause of comming she to tell began.
And comming home, in warlike fresh aray
Scudamour comming to Cares house,
Saw comming home; all voide of doubtfull feare,
And comming to her sonne, gan first to scold,
Which lawlesse multitude him comming too
Which when as Radigund there comming heard,
For comming to this knight, she purpose fayned,
One comming towards her with hasty speede:
He comming neare, gan gently her salute,
Of armed men, comming with close intent
And comming down to seeke them, where they wond,
And comming full before his horses vew,
That brought her backe. And comming present there,
She comming forth, when as she first beheld
But comming to the place, and finding there
Then th'other comming neare, gan him reuile,
The comming of that so much threatned Knight,
Who comming forth yet full of late affray,
But comming to the riuers side, he found
And comming likewise to the wounded knight,
Which when the Saluage comming now in place,
To whom false Turpine comming courteously,
As he this way comming from feastfull glee,
But Calidore soone comming to her ayde,
He chaunst one comming towards him to spy,
The doubtfull Damzell dare not yet commit
Who did her cause into thy hand commit,
Did earnestly commit, and her coniure,
Ne him commit to graue terrestriall,
And safe commit to her soft fethered nest,
T'auenge that shame, they did on him commit;
By meanes whereof, she did at last commit
Whole to commit, and to his dealing iust.
That had almost committed crime abhord,
To plaine of wrongs, which had committed bin
Committed her, yfostered to bee,
And oft committed fowle Idolatree.
Defil'd the pledge committed to thy trust?
By her committed be, of speciall grace,
Of that commixtion they did then beget
Through fowle commixture of his filthy blot;
Was fauoured, and to her grace commmended.
Mote to them for their most commodity
To good and bad, the common Inne of rest;
To taken counsell of their common cares;
Certes was but a common Courtisane,
That it prodigious seemes in common peoples sight.
But on their common harmes together did deuise.
Ne signe of sence did shew, ne common wit,
Her words were not, as common words are ment,
But seeme gainst common sence to them most sweet;
Low looking dales, disloignd from common gaze;
Concord she cleeped was in common reed,
He wore, that seemed strange to common vew,
I doe not forme them to the common line
Where when he vnderstood by common fame,
Fayre Florimell, into the common hall,
Then termes to entertaine of common guize,
And changing all that forme of common weale,
She was about affaires of common wele,
It often fals in course of common life,
Nor lawes of men, that common weales containe,
To common haunts, and companies frequent,
And soothly it was sayd by common fame,
To make a common feast, & feed with gurmandize.
Which mote not be prophan'd of common eyes,
He was to weet by common voice esteemed
About some carcase by the common way,
So long as Guyon with her commoned,
As commonly as friend does with his frend.
Till by consent of Commons and of Peares,
